verses.text: After five days, the high priest Ananias came down with some elders and a lawyer named Tertullus, and they brought their case against Paul before the governor.
verses.comment: Ananias and the Jewish leaders take formal legal action against Paul. The presence of a lawyer highlights the seriousness and formality of this accusation. The original word for lawyer (rhetorician) suggests a skilled orator.

verses.text: When Paul was called in, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying to Felix: 'We have enjoyed much peace because of you, and your reforms are benefitting this nation in every way and everywhere.'
verses.comment: Tertullus starts with flattery towards Felix. Such rhetoric was typical in ancient courtrooms as an appeal to the judge's favor.

verses.text: We gratefully accept these things always and in every place, most excellent Felix.
verses.comment: Tertullus' words underscore the formal tone and the desire to achieve a favorable verdict from Felix.

verses.text: But in order not to trouble you further, I beg you to briefly hear us with your kindness.
verses.comment: The advocate respectfully requests a brief hearing, emphasizing deference to the governor's authority.

verses.text: For we have found this man to be a troublemaker, stirring up riots among all the Jews throughout the world, and a leader of the sect of the Nazarenes.
verses.comment: 'Sect of the Nazarenes' is how early Christians were described by their opponents. The claim that Paul caused riots stretches the truth for legal effect.

verses.text: He even tried to desecrate the temple, so we seized him.
verses.comment: Desecrating the temple was a serious crime under Jewish law (cf. Acts 21:28-29). The accusation against Paul is false, showing opposition to the Gospel was intense and legalistic.

verses.text: [But Lysias the commander came by and with great force took him out of our hands,]
verses.comment: Some manuscripts omit this verse. This sentence shifts blame for not following proper procedure onto the Roman commander.

verses.text: ordering his accusers to come to you. By examining him yourself, you will be able to learn about all these things we are accusing him of.
verses.comment: Tertullus appeals to the governor to investigate Paul, confident in his case. Legal procedures in Rome emphasized personal investigation by the judge.

verses.text: The Jews also joined in the accusation, asserting that these things were so.
verses.comment: Jewish unity against Paul echoes opposition to Jesus before Pilate (cf. Matthew 27:20-23).

verses.text: When the governor motioned for him to speak, Paul replied: 'Knowing that you have been a judge over this nation for many years, I cheerfully make my defense.'
verses.comment: Paul follows protocol by acknowledging the judge. Unlike Tertullus, his praise is direct and restrained, demonstrating both humility and confidence in a just hearing.

verses.text: You can see for yourself that it is no more than twelve days since I went up to worship in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Paul highlights the shortness of his time in Jerusalem, undermining claims of long-term sedition.

verses.text: They did not find me arguing with anyone in the temple, or stirring up a crowd in the synagogues, or anywhere in the city.
verses.comment: Paul’s actions were focused on worship, not rebellion, aligning with the gospel’s call to peace and order (cf. Romans 12:18).

verses.text: Nor can they prove to you the things of which they now accuse me.
verses.comment: Paul appeals to tangible evidence, echoing principles of justice. Christian faith values truth and evidence above accusation—see Deut. 19:15.

verses.text: But I do confess this to you, that according to the Way, which they call a sect, I worship the God of our ancestors, believing everything that is written in the Law and the Prophets.
verses.comment: Paul affirms continuity with Israel’s faith, showing the unity of Old Testament promises and Christian fulfillment. Christians uphold the Law and the Prophets, just as Jesus did (cf. Matthew 5:17-18).

verses.text: I have the same hope in God as they themselves hold—that there will be a resurrection of both the righteous and the wicked.
verses.comment: Paul's belief in the resurrection fulfills prophetic expectation (Daniel 12:2). The universal resurrection has both literal and spiritual significance: God will judge all people, affirming both justice and hope.

verses.text: So I always strive to keep a clear conscience before God and men.
verses.comment: Paul teaches that internal integrity and external behavior matter, echoing Jesus’ teaching on the heart (Matthew 5:8). Purity of conscience is essential for authentic faith.

verses.text: After several years, I came to bring gifts for the poor to my people and to offer sacrifices.
verses.comment: Paul's bringing of alms and sacrifices shows he still deeply respects Temple worship and charitable practices. This supports the importance of both spiritual and sacramental expressions of faith.

verses.text: While I was doing this, they found me purified in the temple, without any crowd or disturbance. But some Jews from Asia—
verses.comment: Paul’s purification observance confirms his faithfulness to the Law. Participation in ritual cleansing is a sign of respect for God’s ordinances.

verses.text: they ought to be here before you and bring charges, if they have anything against me.
verses.comment: Roman and Jewish law required accusers to be present. Paul’s legal defense echoes Deuteronomy 17 about witnesses—Christian justice upholds procedural truth.

verses.text: Otherwise, let these men here state what wrongdoing they found when I stood before the council,
verses.comment: Paul calls for specific testimony. The council (Sanhedrin) reached no solid verdict, showing the injustice of his accusers.

verses.text: unless it is with regard to this one thing I cried out, when standing among them: 'It is concerning the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial before you today.'
verses.comment: Paul points to the real theological issue: resurrection. This belief separates Christ-followers and underlines the apostolic confession. The resurrection remains a core doctrine (cf. 1 Corinthians 15:12-20).

verses.text: Then Felix, who was well informed about the Way, postponed the case, saying, 'When Lysias the commander comes down, I will decide your case.'
verses.comment: Felix's awareness of the Way indicates the growing influence of followers of Jesus even among Roman authorities. Procedural delay allowed for further investigation.

verses.text: He ordered the centurion to keep Paul under guard, but to let him have some freedom and to allow his friends to attend to his needs.
verses.comment: Although still imprisoned, Paul receives a degree of freedom and communal support, reflecting early Christian values of fellowship and care (cf. Acts 2:44-45).

verses.text: After some days Felix came with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish, and he sent for Paul and listened to him speak about faith in Christ Jesus.
verses.comment: Felix’s curiosity brought him to hear about faith in Christ. Drusilla’s presence shows the interest among both pagans and Jews for the Christian message, which is always centered on the person of Jesus as Messiah.

verses.text: But as Paul spoke about righteousness, self-control, and the coming judgment, Felix became afraid and said, 'Go away for now. When I find time I will summon you.'
verses.comment: Paul’s message includes moral conversion and future judgment, key themes in apostolic preaching. Felix’s fear shows the convicting power of Gospel truth and the reality of judgment.

verses.text: At the same time, he was hoping that Paul would give him money. So he often sent for him and talked with him.
verses.comment: Felix’s interest was partly corrupt. The mixing of worldly motives with spiritual matters is a danger warned against throughout Scripture (cf. 1 Timothy 6:10).

verses.text: But after two years had passed, Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus. Because he wanted to do the Jews a favor, Felix left Paul imprisoned.
verses.comment: Paul’s long imprisonment is the result of political calculation. God’s providence still works through such events, preparing Paul for ministry in Rome and demonstrating that the church must endure hardship for the sake of Christ’s name (cf. 2 Timothy 2:8-10).
